introduction.p: If the series\sum a_k converges, then an important result necessarily follows regarding the sequence\{a_n\}. This activity explores this result.
Assume that the series \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k converges and has sum equal to L.

statement.p: What is the nth partial sum S_n of the series \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k?

hint.p: Recall that the nth partial sum is the sum of the first n terms.

solution.p:
The nth partial sum of the series \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k is
S_n = \sum_{k=1}^n a_k .

statement.p: What is the (n-1)st partial sum S_{n-1} of the series \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k?

hint.p: Consider the sum with one fewer term.

solution.p:
The (n-1)st partial sum of the series \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k is
S_{n-1} = \sum_{k=1}^{n-1} a_k .

statement.p: What is the difference between the nth partial sum and the (n-1)st partial sum of the series \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k?
Since we are assuming that \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k = L, what does that tell us about \lim_{n \to \infty} S_n? Why? What does that tell us about \lim_{n \to \infty} S_{n-1}? Why?

hint.p: Remember that the partials sums have to tend to the sum of the series.

solution.p:
Since \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} a_k = \lim_{n \to \infty} S_n we must have \lim_{n \to \infty} S_n = L. Also,
\lim_{n \to \infty} S_n = \lim_{n \to \infty} S_{n-1} , so \lim_{n \to \infty} S_{n-1} = L as well.

statement.p: Combine the results of the previous two parts of this activity to determine \lim_{n \to \infty} a_n = \lim_{n \to \infty} (S_n - S_{n-1}).

hint.p: Note that S_n \to L and S_{n-1} \to L.

solution.p: We have \lim_{n \to \infty} a_n \amp = \lim_{n \to \infty} \left(S_n - S_{n-1}\right)\amp = \lim_{n \to \infty} S_n - \lim_{n \to \infty} S_{n-1}\amp = L - L\amp = 0.
